item.title: C++ Class
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

la­wl:

no, it wont. it will make 500 copies of the class. functions are only defined once, and called with first param being the object (this)

while technically true on gcc, (this is towards frugooscape) on cl, it uses a calling convention named __thiscall, where the ‘this’ pointer is shoved into ecx before calling.

Read full topic

item.title: C++ Class
item.dc:creator: @frugoo_scape frugoo scape
item.description:
@frugoo_scape wrote:

I had a question related to Class Initialization with arrays. I was wondering if I had a array of classes that contained a void would that void be initialized the amount of the size of the array?

Example:

[code]class Test{
void testVoid();
};

Test::testVoid(){
//Do something
}

Test a[500];[/code]

I think this would create 500 copies of the whole class which means the void would be copied too.
When I say copied I mean, 500 individually allocated into ram, not references.
If this is true, I understand that I would have to create a static type void.
I guess, I figured it out on my own by posting this, but I still want to see what other people think about this.

Read full topic
